He spoke little to no English,  and still made the effort to approach the guy to offer a helping hand.
I thought this was cool enough to post, sometimes perspective is all we lack.

author: BancKing 👑
text:
That are catastrophic if they break down, which leads to a cycle of bailouts from the govt, as well as exclusive regulations, that often hamper smaller players in business and investing.
(Aka capital allocators)

author: BancKing 👑
text:
Capital allocation is poor in America because of a top down distribution of new capital instead of a bottom up approach.

New capital goes straight to middle men (aka banks) who then decide who should get the newly minted capital.

Creating  cantillion “controlled” bubbles,

author: BancKing 👑
text: Inflation day

author: BancKing 👑
text: At the core of Web 3, I believe you have a secure data revolution. Liquidity networks not only have the potential to decentralize finance but data collection as well.

author: BancKing 👑
text: The concept behind “data is the new oil” is that just like oil, raw data isn't valuable in and of itself, but, rather, the value is created when it is gathered completely and accurately, connected to other relevant data, and done so in a timely manner.

author: BancKing 👑
text:
Bancor accomplishes the same thing with a key added feature.
Bancor provides a much more rich data set.
The natural progression of web 3 is Billions/Trillions of pools, providing secure market based data about everything.

author: BancKing 👑
text: Dex’s allow users to swap one asset for another on chain, in that sense amm’s like Uniswap accomplish the goal of a new financial primitive.

author: BancKing 👑
text: In my mind the natural progression of this model is professional market participants taking over the role of LP,s, once again centralizing market making into the hands of a few players.

author: BancKing 👑
text: Uniswap v3 is a great example of a “dex”, it’s uses concentrated liquidity to process low slippage trades often times at the expense of the Liquidity provider.
